text:
SPEAKER: So-- I mean,
the region has--

and Jordan have many
range of social problems.

Why did you decide to
prioritize disadvantaged youth?

FADI GHANDOUR: Well, for me, the
issue of youth is where I felt,

one, I could have
the most impact.

Because youth, entrepreneurship,
jobs, employment, I mean,
this is what I do.

Being an entrepreneur,
a businessman,

somebody that runs
a business, you

are in the business
of hiring people.

That's one, number
two, so I wanted

to do things that I
could have impact on,
impact meaning direct impact.

I needed to feel
that I am doing it.

And when I say I, it's
the organization, so--
that we were actively doing it.

But also, the biggest challenge
in the region and maybe

globally, today,
is what do you do

with young people
that are graduating
in droves from universities?

They call it, in the
region, the Arab--
the youth bulge.

So look how derogatory
that word is,

call your future
generations a bulge
or a challenge or a problem--
what do we do with our youth--

rather than thinking of
them as an opportunity.
So how do we actually--

a young society
is an opportunity.

Europe would kill
for a young society.

Even China would kill
for a young society.

Japan has negative
growth in its population.

We have people that are 50,
60% under the age of 25.
That's a massive resource.

But it's also, if it doesn't
get channeled in the right way,

if it doesn't get
the opportunities,

if it doesn't get
the education, if it

doesn't get to feel that it's
part and parcel of society,
it will create havoc in society.

And that's why you
saw the Arab Spring.

And that's why you have--
you see issues in Iraq today.
You see issues in Syria.
You see issues in Egypt.

You know, even in stable
countries, governments,

private sector,
people are worried
about the stability of society.

And it's not only about
health care and the problems
in health care.

It is, at the core of it,
is the young population

that is feeling a sense
of despair, sometimes.

Because they do not
have the opportunities.

And that's why we focused on
youth in marginalized areas.

Because that's where
we're needed most.

And the idea of it was to be
experiential in everything
that we do.

We're in the business
of character building.
